item.title:
R to @captainyosarian: Not that I'm aware of (if you have that `catch`Â¹) provided it really is something where you don't care about the timing of completion.
Â¹ Without the `catch` you'll get an unhandled promise rejection if the promise rejects, which can be less than ideal.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
Not that I'm aware of (if you have that `catch`Â¹) provided it really is something where you don't care about the timing of completion.

Â¹ Without the `catch` you'll get an unhandled promise rejection if the promise rejects, which can be less than ideal.

item.title: R to @wycats: All of this has happened before, and all of it will happen again.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: All of this has happened before, and all of it will happen again.

item.title: Anyone using Zoho Workplace? Any good? Certainly been around forever...
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: Anyone using Zoho Workplace? Any good? Certainly been around forever...

item.title:
R to @tjcrowder: Unsurprisingly, I'm apparently not the only one pushing back on this, there's some "internal issues" on this (#1275359, #234716537) according to Workspace support. But I'm done, it's long past time.
Recommendations for alternative light email + docs welcome!
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
Unsurprisingly, I'm apparently not the only one pushing back on this, there's some "internal issues" on this (#1275359, #234716537) according to Workspace support. But I'm done, it's long past time.

Recommendations for alternative light email + docs welcome!

item.title: So apparently @GoogleWorkspace has decided that they get to tell me to require users to create a browser profile in Chrome? I, as the administrator, don't have the option to allow them to keep doing whatever they were doing before (including not "signing in" to Chrome at all)?
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: So apparently @GoogleWorkspace has decided that they get to tell me to require users to create a browser profile in Chrome? I, as the administrator, don't have the option to allow them to keep doing whatever they were doing before (including not "signing in" to Chrome at all)?

item.title:
R to @tjcrowder: Here's a shock no one saw coming: DM'ing them was a waste of time. Quelle surprise.
I have gotten the issue with their incompetent verification system resolved, but it's nothing to do with their having done anything useful in the DMs.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
Here's a shock no one saw coming: DM'ing them was a waste of time. Quelle surprise.

I have gotten the issue with their incompetent verification system resolved, but it's nothing to do with their having done anything useful in the DMs.

item.title: R to @tjcrowder: (Instead of copying the necessary information over when the user clicked the link from their account page in the first place.)
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: (Instead of copying the necessary information over when the user clicked the link from their account page in the first place.)

item.title: R to @GoogleWorkspace: OK, but I shouldn't have to. This process is asinine, unnecessary, and incompetently done -- all the way down to asking the end user to enter one of two numbers on a page (one 16 digits long, the other 12) and not validating the length to help them avoid entering the wrong one.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: OK, but I shouldn't have to. This process is asinine, unnecessary, and incompetently done -- all the way down to asking the end user to enter one of two numbers on a page (one 16 digits long, the other 12) and not validating the length to help them avoid entering the wrong one.

item.title: R to @tjcrowder: Looking for recommendations for non-Google alternatives. This is just so amazingly awful. I thought continuing with GW once the free service ended would be the path of least resistance. My bad. I'd insert that Simpson's meme but frankly, this sh** just isn't funny.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: Looking for recommendations for non-Google alternatives. This is just so amazingly awful. I thought continuing with GW once the free service ended would be the path of least resistance. My bad. I'd insert that Simpson's meme but frankly, this sh** just isn't funny.

item.title: Wow @GoogleWorkspace, I've seen some truly awful onboarding processes, but yours takes the cake. Photo ID and address verification for a Â£13.80/mo bill?!?! And you can't even process them in a reasonable time? Astonishingly poor.
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: Wow @GoogleWorkspace, I've seen some truly awful onboarding processes, but yours takes the cake. Photo ID and address verification for a Â£13.80/mo bill?!?! And you can't even process them in a reasonable time? Astonishingly poor.

item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
Reflect.apply(theFunction, thisArg, [args]);

rather than

theFunction.apply(thisArg, [args]);

Hope that helps!ðŸ˜€

item.title: R to @tjcrowder: inherit from `Function.prototype`, you can (but shouldn't!) do `Object.setPrototypeOf(theFunction, null)` and the function won't have `apply` anymore (but will still be callable in the normal way). To handle the possibility of such a function, you might use
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: inherit from `Function.prototype`, you can (but shouldn't!) do `Object.setPrototypeOf(theFunction, null)` and the function won't have `apply` anymore (but will still be callable in the normal way). To handle the possibility of such a function, you might use

item.title: R to @tjcrowder: `Reflect.apply`. Aside from its use in Proxy traps, it's good when you need to use `apply` on a function you don't know the origin of. That function could have an overridden version of `apply` you don't want to use, or could have no `apply` at all. A function doesn't *have* to
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description: `Reflect.apply`. Aside from its use in Proxy traps, it's good when you need to use `apply` on a function you don't know the origin of. That function could have an overridden version of `apply` you don't want to use, or could have no `apply` at all. A function doesn't *have* to

item.title:
R to @tjcrowder: allowed to be quite odd (if perhaps not quite so odd as IE8's functions). I think most host environments provide real JavaScript functions now, to avoid issues like the issues with IE8's `setTimeout` and such.
But we don't need a host-provided function to see the usefulness of
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder

allowed to be quite odd (if perhaps not quite so odd as IE8's functions). I think most host environments provide real JavaScript functions now, to avoid issues like the issues with IE8's `setTimeout` and such.

But we don't need a host-provided function to see the usefulness of

item.title: R to @tjcrowder: functions are still allowed to be quite that strange. The spec says the difference between JavaScript functions and host-provided exotic functions "...is not semantically observable..." whatever that means (https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-language-source-code.html#sec-non-ecmascript-functions). But I think host-provided functions are still

item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
environment with functions like that today but that has `Reflect.apply`, you could do:

Reflect.apply(setTimeout, null, [callback, delay]);

and it would work, even though the function wasn't really a function. (I don't recall why I wrote "there still are some [host-provided

item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
item.description:
didn't inherit from `Function.prototype`, had no `call` or `apply`, and `typeof setTimeout` returned `"object"`. It was *callable*, but it wasn't a JavaScript function. Since it has no `apply`, doing:

setTimeout.apply(null, [callback, delay]);

would fail. If there's still an

item.title: R to @garethheyes: A host-provided function is a function provided to the JavaScript engine by the host environment, such as `setTimeout`. It used to be that they didn't have to be actual JavaScript function objects (and it may still be; more in a sec). For instance, IE8's `setTimeout` wasn't. It
item.dc:creator: @tjcrowder
